paper_type_justification: This paper tests whether a pre-trained CNN can detect burial mounds by comparing model predictions to field-verified ground truth data. Claims are about empirical phenomena (model performance, detection rates) rather than presenting a new methodology. The primary contribution is evidence about ML limitations in archaeological prospection.

evidence: Abstract: 'We set out to detect burial mounds in satellite imagery... Results were assessed using field data'
Research design tests whether transfer learning approach works for archaeological feature detection
Two-run design tests prediction about training data selection effects

evidence.claims_structure: Claims test predictions about ML performance. Core claims evaluate whether self-reported metrics predict real-world performance, whether curated training helps, whether transfer learning works.
evidence.methods_application: Systematic hypothesis-testing: apply pre-trained CNN, generate predictions, compare to field-verified ground truth using pre-specified evaluation criteria.
evidence.analytical_workflow: Deductive sequence: design → implement → predict → validate against ground truth → evaluate success/failure

expressed_vs_revealed.mismatch_explanation: Paper explicitly frames comparative evaluation and actually conducts it. No evidence of HARKing.

primary_classification.justification: Clear deductive research testing whether pre-trained CNN approach works for burial mound detection. Hypothesis (transfer learning will work) tested against field-verified ground truth. Two-run design tests secondary hypothesis about training data selection.

transparency_assessment.transparency_notes: Clear methodology description, code repositories provided, validation approach explicit.
